description:
Notothenia rossii, commonly known as the Antarctic rockcod or the Antarctic stone fish, is a species of marine fish belonging to the family Nototheniidae. It is native to the waters around the Antarctic continent and the sub-Antarctic islands.

Notothenia rossii is a demersal fish, meaning it typically inhabits the seafloor or near-bottom environments. It has a robust, elongated body shape with a large, flattened head and a wide mouth. The fish can reach a maximum length of around 70 centimeters (27.6 inches).

The coloration of Notothenia rossii is variable, ranging from dark brown to reddish-brown, with mottled or marbled patterns. This coloration helps the fish blend in with the rocky and kelp-dominated habitats it typically occupies.

As an Antarctic species, Notothenia rossii is adapted to the cold, nutrient-rich waters of the Southern Ocean. It plays an important role in the Antarctic marine ecosystem, serving as a predator of smaller fish, crustaceans, and other invertebrates.

Due to its commercial value, Notothenia rossii has been subject to targeted fishing in the past, leading to concerns about its conservation status. Efforts have been made to manage and regulate the harvest of this species to ensure its long-term sustainability.
